messageBody:
Just about everyone's weighed in on this topic. It's an interesting one.



I'd like to remind that the reason for the name "unit test" is that it
refers to the _scope_ of the components that are being tested, relative to
the entire system. The term "unit testing" should not imply anything too
prescriptive about the strategies employed to test thoroughly at that scope,
though as others have stated, there are guidelines. In object oriented
programming the "unit" scope is often a class, but is also often a single
method or a cluster of closely related classes. Truly, a program can be
broken into even smaller units - expressions and statements - but everyone
agrees this is too granular for testing.

Also recall that the test of whether we've tested _enough_ should be code
coverage analysis of the component/subsystem/system under test when run
against our test suite. If testing all the public and protected methods
also happens to test your private methods and exception handlers thoroughly,
then you're all set, but you don't know that unless you have extremely
simple applications, or you are doing coverage analysis. Anyway, it is
unsafe to conclude a priori that public API testing is all that is needed;
each situation should determine the tools and strategies used.

I have two examples to offer that may help when you're in a tough situation
where testing private methods or protected classes.

One is a private field accessor class, the other is a technique.

I'm attaching the FieldAccessor, which is mainly from Larman and Guthrie's
Java 2 performance and idiom book. Personally, I have yet to need this
class for anything, but I thought I'd pass it along. It's javadoc'ed.

The technique is one that I have found useful at least once, which is to put
a public static inner class that extends junit.framework.TestCase in the
class under test. This gives the inner class full access to the outer
class's private methods and members, while allowing the inner class to be an
instance of a JUnit test case. I sent an example of this to this list a few
weeks ago. Another handy thing is that when you compile the outer class,
the inner test case is produced in a separate class file which can be safely
deleted when packaging the outer class for production (because the outer
class makes no references to the static inner class).

Scott Stirling
Macromedia

First of all I have to mention that I'm pretty novice when it comes to

use
JUnit for writing unittests. But I have a question which I hope some of

you
can help me with - it's regarding testing private/protected methods and

how
to organize my test package.



First the package. I have read to articles regarding test ("Junit best

practices" from JavaWorld and "Incremental development with Ant and

JUnit" from developerWorks). In the JBT article Andy Schneider advice you to

keep
tests in the same location as the source code. And in the Incremental...

article Malcolm Davis advice you to make a separate package. Which

approach is the best to use?



I must admit that I like the idea of making a separate package but then

again - how do I then test private and protected methods? And if I keep

the
tests in the same location as the source code - who do I then test

private methods?



I would very much appreciate if some of you could give me a little

example



Kind regards,



J. Andersen
